_meanings:
{@--1@} Direct perception or 
cognition, knowledge derived from 
personal observation or experiment, 
notion, apprehension, the impression
on the mind not derived from 
memory, one of the kinds of 
knowledge; {#sarvavyavahAraheturjYAnaM budDiH . sA dviviDA#}
{#smftiranuBavaSca . saMskAramAtrajanyaM jYAnaM smftiH .#}
{#tadBinnaM jYAnamanuBavaH#} which again is  
{#yaTArTa#} right & {#ayaTArTa#} wrong. See  
<ls>T. S. 34.</ls> (The Naiyāyikas recognize
{#pratyakza, anumAna, upamAna#} and {#SAbda#} as
the four sources of knowledge;
the Vedāntins and Mīmāṃsakas
add two more {#arTApatti#} and  
{#anupalabDi#}; the Vaiśeṣikas and Bauddhas
admit the first two only, the
Sāṃkhyas exclude {#upamA#}, while the
Cārvākas admit {#pratyakza#} only. Other
sections of philosophical schools
add three more to the six sources
of knowledge recognised by the
Mīmāṃsakas; {#--saMBava#} ‘equivalence’;
{#Etihya#} ‘fallible testimony’, and {#cezwA#}
‘gesture’.)
